questions.question: What is the chemical formula for the metal-organic framework that exhibits record N2 capacities and selectivities for the removal of N2 from mixtures with CH4?
What is the role of vanadium(ii) centers in the adsorption mechanism of the metal-organic framework V2Cl2.8(btdd)?
questions.answer: Vanadium(ii) centers in V2Cl2.8(btdd) are capable of back-donating electron density to weak π acids, enabling selective nitrogen adsorption via backbonding interactions.

questions.question: How does the adsorption isotherm of N2 at 25°C in V2Cl2.8(btdd) compare to the adsorption isotherm of CH4 at the same temperature?
questions.answer: V2Cl2.8(btdd) adsorbs substantially more N2 than CH4 below 1 bar at 25°C, indicating a higher selectivity for N2 over CH4.

questions.question: True or False: The adsorption of N2 in V2Cl2.8(btdd) is fully reversible, as shown by successive adsorption/desorption cycles with no loss in capacity.
What experimental technique was used to confirm the accessibility and electron-donating ability of the square-pyramidal vanadium(ii) centers in V2Cl2.8(btdd)?
questions.answer: In situ infrared spectroscopy was used, where a single band appears at 2,084 cm–1 after CO dosing, indicating the presence of vanadium binding site and demonstrating a backbonding interaction.

questions.question: What is the significance of the isosteric heat of adsorption value for N2 in V2Cl2.8(btdd)?
questions.answer: The isosteric heat of adsorption of −56 kJ mol−1 for N2 in V2Cl2.8(btdd) is the largest value reported for a porous material exhibiting reversible N2 binding, indicating strong adsorption.

questions.question: True or False: The IAST selectivity for N2 over CH4 in V2Cl2.8(btdd) decreases significantly when the temperature is raised from 25°C to 45°C.
What is the role of backbonding in the adsorption of olefins such as ethylene and propylene in V2Cl2.8(btdd)?
questions.answer: Backbonding interactions with the olefin π* orbitals in V2Cl2.8(btdd) lead to strong yet reversible adsorption of olefins, enabling selective capture even at high temperatures.

questions.question: True or False: The ethylene selectivity values exhibited by V2Cl2.8(btdd) at elevated temperatures suggest that this material may be effective for the separation of ethylene in ethane-rich feeds.
What experimental evidence supports the presence of a mixture of vanadium(ii) and vanadium(iii) in the framework of V2Cl2.8(btdd)?
questions.answer: Vanadium K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy revealed an edge energy consistent with the presence of a mixture of vanadium(ii) and vanadium(iii), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy indicated the presence of both bridging and terminal chloride ligands.

questions.question: True or False: The synthesis of V2Cl2.8(btdd) was supported by the Hydrogen Materials—Advanced Research Consortium (HyMARC) as part of the Energy Materials Network.
What is the significance of the V–N separation distance observed in the structure of V2Cl2.8(btdd) after dosing with N2?
questions.answer: The V–N separation distance of 2.12(7) Å is the shortest metal–N2 interaction reported amongst metal–organic frameworks, indicating a strong interaction between vanadium and N2.

questions.question: True or False: The adsorption mechanism of V2Cl2.8(btdd) cannot distinguish gases through backbonding.
What challenges have previously prohibited the synthesis of a material with reducing, coordinatively unsaturated vanadium(ii) centers?
questions.answer: Challenges include the kinetic inertness of vanadium(ii), susceptibility towards oxidation, and reactivity with carboxylate-containing ligands, which have previously prohibited the synthesis of such materials.

questions.question: True or False: The discovery of V2Cl2.8(btdd) expands the molecular properties that can be targeted by solid adsorbents to discriminate gases in industrial processes.
